title: **Preparation and isolation of E7.5 mouse embryos**
body: All mice used in this study are housed in a modern, air-conditioned facility and maintained according to NIH guidelines.

body.body: To obtain post-implantation embryos for epiblast grafting, timed-pregnant female ICR \(CD-1) mice were prepared by mating with ICR male mice and midday on the day of appearance of a vaginal plug was designated as 0.5 days post coitum \(dpc).
Pregnant mice were euthanized by cervical dislocation at the appropriate gestation stage \(midday of day 7 after appearance of a vaginal plug).

After euthanizing the mother, 7.5 dpc \(E7.5) mouse embryos \(no allantoic bud \(OB) - early allantoic bud \(EB) stage, or OB/EB stage) were removed from decidua following the procedures described in “Manipulating the mouse embryo: a laboratory manual \(Third Edition)” with minor modifications \(steps 4-9).

Pinch the skin with a forceps and make a small lateral incision around the midline with regular scissors. Hold the skin above and below the incision and expose the abdomen by pulling the skin toward head and tail. Cut the peritoneum with a watchmaker’s forceps and fine scissors. Push the gut away and locate the two horns of the uterus, the oviducts, and the ovaries.

Grab one of the uterine horns with a watchmaker’s forceps and cut the vaginal end of the uterus with fine scissors. Carefully remove mesometrium and fat along the uterus and then cut the ovarian end with fine scissors.

The embryos appear as “beads on a string” along the entire length of the uterus. Cut into the individual swellings containing the embryo with fine scissors. The muscle layer is removed with a pair of forceps: slide one pair of forceps between muscle layer and decidual tissue and remove muscle layer with second pair of forceps.
Repeat this procedure with the other uterine horn.
Transfer all isolated embryos to a new Petri dish containing pre-warmed embryo dissection media.
To remove embryo from the decidua, first pierce deciduum with forceps and open forceps to tear two sides apart and shell out the embryo with the tips of closed forceps.

title: **Preparation of non-intact and non-viable mouse embryos for grafting**

body.body: Insert the closed tips of one pair of watchmaker’s forceps into the yolk sac cavity close to the ectoplacental cone and pin the embryo to the bottom of the Petri dish.

body: Insert the closed tips of a second pair of watchmaker’s forceps at the same location and slowly remove the tissues containing Reichert’s membrane, parietal endoderm as well as majority of the trophoblast layer which is part of the parietal yolk sac completely from the embryos by moving the second forceps toward the distal part of the cylinder, resulting in a non-intact and non-viable OB/EB stage embryo \(Figure

body.body: The ectoplacental cone region was left intact for better culture outcome.

Grafting cells into the non-intact and non-viable OB/EB stage embryo epiblast was performed manually with an aspirator tube assembly \(Drummond) and a hand-pulled glass capillary \(Drummond, Microcaps, 50 µl).
Before grafting, wash the cells twice with 1x PBS.
Scratch a colony of cells used for grafting off culture plates with a pipette tip mounted to a 20ul micropipette. With a tungsten needle cut the colony into small pieces containing 40–50 cells.
During grafting held the embryo loosely with forceps, and insert the pulled glass capillary into anterior, posterior or distal regions of the epiblast depending on grafting locations.

A small volume of dissection medium was expelled out from the tip of the capillary to make an opening in the epiblast and as a result sections of the epiblast/ectoderm, mesoderm and/or endoderm cells were removed from the embryo to further ensure the embryo is in a non-intact and non-viable status prior to grafting.
For grafting, a small clump of 40-50 cells was gently placed inside the opening and the glass capillary was slowly drawn out of the embryo.
After grafting the non-intact embryos were cultured in embryo culture medium as described previously<sup>9</sup> in a Nunc 4 well dish.
36 hours post-grafting, cultured embryos were washed twice with 1x PBS and fixed in 4% PFA overnight at 4°C and subsequently used for immunohistochemical analysis.
